You generate image requests for a lesson background/whiteboard animation.

Given narration text, identify places where a concept/object should appear visually.
Do NOT be obnoxious: pick visuals that actually help understanding, like a teacher drawing.

In every place where an image could link to speech well, do request an imageDiagram behavior:
- Some concepts can persist for a while, using or being represented with some image, so leave a special image there 
- Mark those as diagram=1.
- Anything that will actually be interacted with after the fisrt seconds of being drawn is a diagram = 1- you SHOULDNT constantly request diagrams though as they take ~30secs to load -> try and use them  only after some "time" has passed in the chunk.- Small one-off visuals are diagram=0.

Sync behavior:
- You must sync each image to the narration via word indices.
- Indices are ZERO-BASED word positions after splitting the entire narration by whitespace.
- Provide range_start and range_end (end is INCLUSIVE) -> end should be only where the image.stops being relevant, so try persist solid ranges

Output:
- Query for each image (litterally name) - YOU ARE REQUESTING AN OBJECT AND NOTHING MORE -> APPLES, BANNANAS, 1 -2 WORDS PER OBJECCT- Output must follow the provided JSON schema exactly.
- Keep requested images as concrete things, easily gotten with img gen / search engines.
- Have different objects all around -> do not request the same thing in different places -> if it's used for a while JUST GIVE A BIG RANGE FOR IT

Narration text:
Today we're going to focus on microscopy, stains, and a couple of practical lab activities that will help you connect what you see under the scope to the structures inside the cell. >2.0

Let's begin with an overview of the main types of microscopy and what each one is best at showing. >2.0

First, bright-field light microscopy — the standard compound microscope most of you have used — is excellent for seeing overall cell shapes, the arrangement of cells in a tissue, and larger structures like cell walls in plants or large vacuoles. >2.0 It gives a broad picture but generally lacks the contrast or resolution to show fine internal detail unless you use stains. >1.5

Next, phase-contrast microscopy is designed for live cells. >2.0 It enhances contrast by converting phase shifts in light passing through transparent specimens into differences in brightness, so you can see live cells, organelle movement, changes in shape, or processes like mitosis without staining. >2.0 This is ideal when you want to observe living behavior without killing or fixing the sample. >1.5

Fluorescence microscopy is used when you want to visualize specific proteins, organelles, or molecules. >2.0 By attaching fluorescent dyes or fluorescent protein tags to a target, you can make just that component light up against a dark background. >2.0 That lets you localize a protein precisely — for example, a membrane protein versus a nuclear protein — and in many cases you can do multi-color labeling to see several targets at once. >1.5

Finally, electron microscopy — including transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) — gives you ultrastructural detail at very high resolution. >2.0 TEM can reveal internal structures like membranes, ribosomes, and cytoskeletal filaments at the nanometer scale, while SEM shows surface topology. >2.0 The trade-off is that samples must be fixed and processed, so you cannot observe live dynamics. >1.5

Any questions so far about which microscope to choose for a particular question? >1.5

Now let's talk about common stains and fluorescent markers that you will commonly encounter in the lab. >2.0 One of the most widely used DNA stains is DAPI. >1.5 DAPI binds strongly to A-T rich regions in DNA and fluoresces blue under UV excitation, so it makes nuclei very easy to identify in fixed cells. >2.0 Because it binds DNA, it's specifically useful if your goal is to visualize the nucleus, count cells by nuclear number, or look at nuclear morphology. >1.5

For mitochondria, MitoTracker dyes are commonly used. >2.0 MitoTracker is a cell-permeant fluorescent probe that accumulates in active mitochondria, and because some variants are retained after fixation, you can label mitochondria in live cells and then fix them for imaging. >1.5 Note that MitoTracker accumulation depends on membrane potential, so it reports active mitochondria rather than all mitochondrial structures. >2.0

To visualize F-actin, fluorescent phalloidin is widely used. >2.0 Phalloidin is a toxin derived from a mushroom that binds specifically to filamentous actin; when conjugated to a fluorophore it gives crisp labeling of actin filaments. >1.5 Be aware that fluorescent phalloidin is typically used on fixed and permeabilized cells because it does not cross intact membranes efficiently. >2.0

A quick word about safety and handling when working with stains and dyes: many fluorescent dyes and stains are irritants or toxic at some concentration, and some, like methanol or DAPI, are harmful if inhaled or absorbed. >2.0 Always consult the safety data sheet (SDS) for each reagent, wear appropriate PPE — gloves, lab coat, eye protection — work in a fume hood when required, and dispose of waste according to institutional protocols. >2.0 When working with live cells and vital dyes, follow biosafety guidelines for the organism and keep culture sterility in mind. >1.5

Let's move from concepts to a hands-on mini-lab you can do to practice basic microscopy: preparing a cheek cell slide and observing it under the light microscope. >2.0 I'll walk you through the steps carefully and include tips to make sure you get a good preparation. >1.5

First, obtain a sterile cotton swab or a sterile foam swab and gently rub the inside of your cheek — the inner buccal mucosa — for a few seconds to collect epithelial cells. >2.0 Be gentle to avoid discomfort; a light, rolling motion collects cells without scraping. >1.5

Next, smear the material from the swab onto a clean microscope slide. >2.0 Make a thin, even smear by rolling the swab lightly across the slide surface; thin smears spread the cells so they are not piled on top of each other. >1.5 Then allow the smear to air dry completely. >1.0

Once dry, you will fix the cells briefly to preserve structure. >2.0 A common and simple fixative is methanol; immerse the slide in methanol for a short, defined time — for example, about 1–2 minutes — or apply a few drops to cover the smear. >2.0 Fixation both kills any remaining cells and helps the cells adhere to the slide, making them easier to stain and observe. >1.5

After fixation, stain the smear with methylene blue for one minute. >2.0 Apply enough methylene blue to cover the smear, wait 60 seconds, and then rinse gently with distilled water to remove excess stain. >1.5 Methylene blue stains nucleic acids and highlights the nucleus strongly while lightly shading the cytoplasm, so you'll be able to see both the nucleus and the cell boundary. >2.0

Finally, allow the slide to air dry or gently blot the edges, then add a drop of mounting medium or even a drop of water and place a coverslip over the smear to prepare it for observation. >2.0 Start viewing the slide under low power to find a good area, then switch to 40x or 100x objectives for better detail. >1.5 Under 40x–100x you should be able to see the cell boundary — the roughly polygonal shape of squamous epithelial cells — and the darker-staining nucleus inside. >2.0 Can you picture what that will look like? >1.5

A couple of practical tips: when rinsing, avoid letting water run heavily over the smear which can wash cells away; when using the 100x oil objective, use immersion oil and be careful with coverslips to avoid bubbles. >2.0 And remember to clean and return materials according to your lab's biohazard and sharps policies. >1.5

Now for a suggestion for a simple live-cell observation you can do if you have access to an appropriate setup: observing yeast budding or fibroblast migration under phase-contrast microscopy. >2.0 Both of these are great examples of dynamic cellular behavior visible without staining. >1.5

If you choose yeast budding, grow a small culture of Saccharomyces cerevisiae to the exponential phase, place a droplet on a slide with a coverslip, and observe under phase contrast. >2.0 You should be able to see mother cells with small daughter buds forming and separating; watch for multiple budding events over time. >1.5 This is safe in a teaching lab when using standard baker’s yeast, but follow your institution's guidelines for handling microorganisms, minimize aerosol generation, and sterilize or dispose of cultures properly. >2.0

If you prefer to observe cultured fibroblast migration, use cells in a small tissue-culture dish on a heated stage if possible, and image them by phase contrast over time-lapse. >2.0 You can see lamellipodia extending, cells polarizing, and net movement across the substrate. >1.5 For safety, work with established cell lines under appropriate biosafety level conditions, use sterile technique to avoid contamination, and handle media and waste per protocols. >2.0 Both experiments demonstrate why phase-contrast is so useful: you can follow living processes without staining or killing the cells. >1.5

Before we finish this section, a quick mini-check to make sure the key points have stuck: which stain would you use to visualize DNA and why? >2.0 Think about the properties we discussed — where the stain binds and what it highlights. >1.5

Finally, we'll review what we've covered and assess understanding with short tasks. >2.0 We'll go over microscopy types and their uses, the common stains and what they label, the cheek cell slide procedure, and options for live-cell observation, and then I'll ask you to apply that knowledge to short practical questions. >2.0

If you have any questions about the procedures, safety precautions, or the choice of stain or microscope for a particular observation, ask now and we'll work through them together. >2.0
